title-group.article-title: Two new species of Allorhogas (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Doryctinae) from southeast Brazil reared from seed pods of Inga vera Willd. and Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) (Fabaceae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Two new species of
Allorhogas
( Hymenoptera , Braconidae , Doryctinae ) from southeast Brazil reared from seed pods of
Inga vera Willd.
and
Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.)
( Fabaceae )
TAMIRES CAMILA TALAMONTE DE OLIVEIRA ¹ ,† , ERNESTO SAMACÁ SÁENZ 2,3 , LUCAS DEL BIANCO FARIA 4 & ALEJANDRO ZALDÍVAR RIVERÓN 3,*
¹Programa de Pós-graduação em Entomologia, Departamento de Entomologia, Universidade Federal de Lavras – UFLA , Campus Universitário, CP 3037, CEP 37200-000, Lavras, MG, Brazil

2
Departamento de Biología Celular y Fisiología. Instituto de Investigaciones Biomédicas. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México , 3er Circuito Exterior s/n, Cd. Universitaria, Copilco, Coyoacán, A. P. 70-228, C. P. 04510 Ciudad de México , México

3
Colección Nacional de Insectos, Instituto de Biología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México , 3er Circuito Exterior s/n, Cd. Universitaria, Copilco, Coyoacán, A. P. 70-233, C. P. 04510 Ciudad de México , México

4
Department of Ecology and Conservation, Institute of Natural Science, Federal University of Lavras, Lavras, Brazil
† Current address
*Corresponding author: Ễ azaldivar@ib.unam.mx; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5837-1929

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Two new species of
Allorhogas
( Braconidae : Doryctinae ),
Al. lavraensis
sp. nov
and
Al. margitae
sp. nov .
, which were reared from seed pods of Fabaceae species, are described from southeast Brazil .
Allorhogas lavraensis
forms seed galls on
Inga vera Willd.
, whereas
Al. margitae
predates on seeds of
Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.)
without making galls. The latter represents the first report of seed predation by a species of
Allorhogas
on the genus
Anadenanthera
.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words:
Fabaceae , COI
, phytophagous , Integrated taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The first evidence of phytophagy in the Braconidae was reported by
in a species of
Allorhogas
from Brazil , which was later described as
Al. dyspistus (Marsh 1991)
. This species was observed feeding on immature seeds of
Pithecellobium tortum Martius
( Fabaceae ) (
). Additional species of
Allorhogas
have been subsequently reared from leguminous seeds, including specimens assigned to
Al. argentinus (Bréthes 1922)
from Costa Rica by
but which actually belong to an undescribed species,
Al. brasiliensis Marsh 2000
from
Balizia pedicellaris (DC.) Barnaby & J.W. Grimes
(cited as
Pithecellobium
),
Al. hansoni Marsh, 2002
from
Inga vera Willd
,
Al. mineiro Zaldívar-Riverón and Martínez, 2019
from
S. adstringens (Mart.) (
Zaldívar-Riverón et al . 2018
)
,
Anadenanthera spermaphagus Marsh, 2000
from Stryphynodendron polyphyllum (
), and
Al. vulgaris
from
Senegalia tenuifolia (Linnaeus) Britton and Rose (
Zaldívar-Riverón et al . 2018
)
.

The senior author recently collected in the state of Minas Gerais , southeast Brazil , several specimens of
Allorhogas
feeding on seed galls on
I. vera
, a widely distributed Fabaceae plant species for which another species of
Allorhogas
,
Al. hansoni ( Marsh 2002 )
, has been reared from pods of the same host plant in Costa Rica (
). However, our morphological examination of the specimens from Brazil revealed that they belong to an undescribed species. Here we describe this new species of
Allorhogas
and an additional species collected in the same locality reared from seeds of
Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) Brenan
( Fabaceae ). We also molecularly characterise the two newly described species with DNA barcoding sequence data and provide information about their biology.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Host plants, fruit collection and insect rearing

The two described species were reared from two Fabaceae species,
I. vera
and
An. colubrina (Vell.)
.
Inga vera
is native in Brazil , though its geographic distribution extends to South and Central America (
).This species has significant economic potential for reforestation, and it is employed as food resource both for humans and other animals (
). Flowers of
I. vera
bloom from August to September, with the fruits maturing in December and January (Lorenzi 2002). We collected 450 fruits from five trees of
I. vera
in December 2019 and 2020, January 2020 , and January 2021 , in areas located in the University Federal de Lavras, southwest Minas Gerais , Brazil (I1– 21°14’6.9” S 044°58’28.22” W ; I2– 21° 13’46.17” S , 044°58’58.87” W ; I3– 21° 13’53.39” S , 044° 58’47.47” W ; I4- 21°13’51.55” S , 044°59’3.71” W ; I5– 21°13’39.18” S , 044° 58’.58.47” W).
Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) Brenan
, commonly known in Brazil as ‘ Angico’ , is a species native to this country. This plant occurs from Northeast to Southern Brazil , occurring in three phytogeographic domains, Atlantic, Caatinga, and Cerrado forests (
). We collected 120 fruits from four trees of
An. colubrina
on 25 th of April and 1 st of May 2019 within the University Federal de Lavras in Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 21°30’36.9” S 044°54’01.7” W ; 21°31’47.5”S – 044°53’21.2” W ; 21°30’39.7” S – 044°54’15.8” W , 21°30’40.8” S – 044°54’28.1” W ).

sec.title: DNA Barcoding
sec.p:
We molecularly characterized the two newly described species generating DNA sequences belonging to the barcoding locus (Hebert et al. 2003; GenBank accession nos PP162906-07). We extracted genomic DNA of one specimen of each species using the EZ-10 spin column animal genomic DNA miniprep kit (Bio Basic) following the manufacturer’s protocol. We amplified a 629 bp of the cytochrome oxidase I (COI) mitochondrial DNA gene using the primers HCO 1490 and LCO 2198 (
) and the Apex Taq RED Master Mix 2X (Apex Bioresearch Products). Reactions consisted of 00:45 s at 94º C for initial denaturation, followed by 35 cycles of 00:15 s annealing 52 º C, and 00:30 s at 75° C for the extension.Amplicons were Sanger sequenced at the University of Arizona Genetics Core.

Uncorrected pairwise distances were calculated for the examined COI fragment with the program PAUP* version 4.0a (
) between specimens of the two new species and those of six species that are morphologically similar to them, and that were nested in a clade exclusively composed of species that attack seeds of
Fabaceae (Samacá-Sáenz et al ., 2022)
. COI sequences of
Al. amuzgo
and
Al. vulgaris
were generated in a previous study (Genbank accession nos JX462512 and MN646961, respectively;
), whereas those of
A. hansoni
,
Al. mineiro
,
Al. infuscotarsus
and
Al. aff. argentinus
were skimmed from previously published raw UCE data (SRA nos SRX1121089, SRX7055025, SRX1120881, and SRX11210903, respectively; Samacá-Sáenz et al . 2019, 2022). COI sequences were aligned using MEGA 10 software (
). The resulting alignment was revised based on the translated amino acids.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: DNA barcoding data

The uncorrected COI distances between
Al. lavraensis
sp. nov.
and
Al. margitae
sp. nov.
and between these new species and the four described species belonging to the “ Fabaceae ” clade of
Allorhogas
were considerably higher than the 2% barcoding distance threshold (7.3 to 12.7 and 7.2 to 10.8%, respectively). The COI distance between
Al. lavraensis
sp. nov.
and
S. hansoni
, which also was reared from pod seeds of
I. vera
, was considerably high (7.8%). Below we morphologically describe these two new species and provide detailed information about their host plant association.

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new species of Allorhogas (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Doryctinae) from southeast Brazil reared from seed pods of Inga vera Willd. and Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) (Fabaceae)

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis .
Allorhogas lavraensis
sp. nov.
and
Al. hansoni
, the latter described from Costa Rica , are associated with seed galls of
I. vera
. L, both forming galls “in the aril or nutritious layer outside of the seed” ( Marsh 2002 ). However,
Al. lavraensis
sp. nov.
can be morphologically distinguished from
Al. hansoni
mainly by having 1) a body yellow with at least lateral mesoscutal and anterior part of the median mesoscutal lobes dark brown (entirely yellow in
Al. hansoni
); 2) tarsomeres brown to dark brown (yellow, occasionally apical tarsomeres brown in
Al. hansoni
); 3) ovipositor about 0.8 × as long as metasoma (almost twice longer than metasoma in
Al. hansoni
); and 4) propodeum strongly rugose-areolate, slightly rugose-coriaceous basally (basal median areas smooth to slightly coriaceous, lateral areas rugose in
Al. hansoni
).

Allorhogas lavraensis
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from the remaining described species of
Allorhogas
that are known to attack seeds of Fabaceae (
Al. brasiliensis
,
Al. mineiro
,
Al. spermaphagus
,
Al. vulgaris
and to
Al. aff argentinus
from Costa Rica ) and other morphologically similar species without rearing records (
Al. amuzgo Martínez & Zaldívar-Riverón 2013
;
Al. infuscotarsus Marsh 2002
) by the combination of the above and the following features: 1) fore wing vein r 0.7 × as long as 3RSa; 2) fore wing vein m-cu interstitial to 2RS; and 4) second and basal half of third metasomal tergites costate-carinate, apical half of third and remaining tergites finely coriaceous.

Description. Female. Body size 3.3 mm (
), fore wing 3.0 mm. Colour : body entirely yellow, lateral mesoscutal and anterior part of median mesoscutal lobes dark brown; scape and pedicel light brown, flagellomeres dark brown to black; eyes silverish black; ocelli brown, area surrounding ocelli dark brown to black; palpi yellow; tarsomeres brown to dark brown; claws dark brown; wings hyaline; fore wing veins brown, stigma brown; hind wing veins brown; ovipositor sheaths dark brown to black, ovipositor yellow, apex strongly sclerotised.
Legs : hind coxa with distinct, pointed basoventral tooth, with large, dense pilosity, ventrally coriaceous rugose. Hind femur 3.4 × longer than wide.
Variation. Body size 2.9–3.2 mm . Antenna with 27–28 flagellomeres.

Male . Similar to female (
). Body size 2.9–3.1 mm . Darker areas of mesosoma and metasoma extending to anterior part of mesopleuron, most part of propodeum and median areas of all tergites. Antenna with 27–28 flagellomeres. Hind femur swollen, about 2.6–2.7 × longer than wide.

p.tp:material-citation:
Holotype .
Female ( CNIN IBUNAM ). Brasil , Minas Gerais , Lavras , UFLA , 21° 13’ 46” S 44° 58’ 58.87” W , ex.
Inga vera
seeds
,
16.I.2020
, I2 FR23, T.C.T. Oliveira col.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Paratypes .
( CNIN-IBUNAM ). Twelve males , 12 females . Same data as holotype, reared 16.I.2020 , 13.I.2021 , T.C.T. Oliveira
.

Biology. A total of 167 adult specimens of
Al. lavraensis
were reared from the pod seeds of
I. vera
. The host seeds were deformed on the nutritious layer outside of the seed, indicating that they had formed galls (
). We did not find evidence of parasitoidism in this species since there were no remains of other insects inside the gall chamber. Similar to a previous report by Morales-Silva & Modesto-Zampieron (2017) , we found three unidentified species of
Eurytoma
( Eurytomidae ) in various seeds where we reared specimens of
Al. lavraensis
(
), although the number of specimens of these
Eurytoma species
was considerably lower compared with the number of
Al. lavraensis
reared (
Eurytoma sp. 1
n= 4,
Eurytoma sp. 2
n= 5,
Eurytoma sp. 3
n= 5,
Al. lavraensis
n=167, respectively;
). This indicates strongly that
Al. lavraensis
is a gall-inducing species on seeds, whereas the species of
Eurytoma
could be parasitoids, though this has yet to be confirmed. Members of
Eurytoma
have been previously suggested to be ectoparasitoids of other species of
Allorhogas
( Morales-Silva & Modesto-Zampieron 2017 ; Penteado-Dias & Carvalho 2008 ;
Tuller et al. 2015
).

The pods and seeds of
I. vera
support a wide insect community composed of 47 species, most of which are herbivores and parasitoids interacting with each other (
Oliveira et al. 2023
). The seed feeders affect up to 3.5% of the seeds, with
Al. lavraensis
accounting for 11.8% (n=167) of the herbivorous specimens. We observed a maximum of seven
Al. lavraensis
specimens forming galls in a single seed with a minimum of one specimen per seed. We found up to six seeds in the same pod with
Al. lavraensis
galls, but more frequently only one seed was predated by
Al. lavraensis
in the same fruit. Each pod had between three and 11 seeds each, with a median of seven seeds per fruit.
Etymology. The name of this species refers to the city where its type specimens were collected, Lavras, in Minas Gerais state , southeast Brazil .

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new species of Allorhogas (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Doryctinae) from southeast Brazil reared from seed pods of Inga vera Willd. and Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) (Fabaceae)

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Allorhogas margitae Oliveira, Samacá-Sáenz & Zaldívar-Riverón
sp. nov. (Figures 4A–F).

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis. This new species can be morphologically distinguished from the species of
Allorhogas
which were reared from Fabaceae species and which are mentioned in the diagnosis of
Al. lavraensis
by having a: 1) body honey yellow with lateral mesoscutal lobes, anterior edge of mesopleuron and propodeum dark brown, legs pale yellow; 2) tarsomeres brown to dark brown; 3) fore wing vein r about as long as vein 3RSa; 4) fore wing vein m-cu interstitial to 2RS; propodeum rugose-areolate, slightly rugose and coriaceous basally; and 6) ovipositor 0.7 × as long as metasoma.

Description. Female. Body size 3.5 mm (Fig. 4A), fore wing 3.0 mm. Colour : body entirely honey yellow, lateral mesoscutal lobes, anterior edge of mesopleuron and propodeum dark brown; scape and pedicel dark brown to black, flagellomeres dark brown to black; eyes silverish black; ocelli black, area surrounding ocelli yellow; palpi pale yellow; legs pale yellow, tarsomeres brown to dark brown; claws brown; wings hyaline; fore wing veins brown, stigma brown; hind wing veins brown; ovipositor sheaths dark brown to black, ovipositor yellow, apex strongly sclerotized black.

Head : transverse in dorsal view, 1.5 × wider than its median length (dorsal view) (Fig. 4B), and 0.85 × as long as high (lateral view); occipital carina complete and reaching hypostomal carina before mandible; post ocellar line (POL) as long than ocellar diameter (OD), 0.5 × ocular ocellar line (OOL); vertex, frons, and temple acinosecoriaceous, gena coriaceous; face sparsely pilose, rugose (Fig. 4B); frons excavation distinct, without a median longitudinal carina, not defined by sharp lateral margins; clypeus with dense and long pilosity; eye 1.3 × longer than wide; eye width 2.3 × longer than temple in dorsal view; malar space 0.4 × eye height and 2.0 × longer than width of hypoclypeal depression; mandibles tridentate; antenna with at least 11 flagellomeres (broken), first flagellomere about 4 × longer than wide, 1.15 × longer than second flagellomere.

Mesosoma : 2.3 × longer than high (Fig. 4D) and 1.6 × longer than wide (Fig. 4C); pronotal collar short, nonvisible in dorsal view, pronotal furrow wide, rugose; mesoscutum transverse in dorsal view, its median length 0.95 × its width; mesoscutal lobes coriaceus-acinose, sparsely pilose along notauli; median mesoscutal lobe with poorly defined longitudinal furrow; notauli wide, deep and scrobiculate, not meeting, reaching the end of mesoscutum in a longitudinally rugose-acinose area; scutellar disc acinose, prescutellar furrow with six transverse carinae; mesopleuron coriaceus; subalar groove wide and scrobiculate; precoxal sulcus wide, deep, smooth, running along most part of mesopleuron; metapleuron entirely rugose—areolate; propodeum rugose-areolate, coriaceous basally, with two indistinct diverging carinae.

Wings : fore wing 3.0 × longer than wide (Fig. 4G). Pterostigma 4 × as long as wide and 0.65 × as long as R. Vein r about as long as 3RSa, 0.4 × as long as 3RSb, and as long as r-m. Vein 2RS interstitial with m-cu, vein RS+Mb absent. Hind wing vein M + CU 0.9 × as long as 1 M, vein m-cu slightly curved towards wing base.
Legs : hind coxa with distinct, pointed basoventral tooth, sparsely pilose, ventrally coriaceous. Hind femur 4.1 × longer than wide.

Metasoma : first tergite 1.4 × wider than long, costate-punctate, with two longitudinal carinae running at the base; transverse basal carina distinct (Fig. 4F). Second and basal half of third tergite costate—slightly punctate, line between second and third tergites distinct and straight; apical half of third punctate, fourth tergite mostly smooth, slightly costate, remaining tergites smooth. Ovipositor 0.7 × as long as metasoma.
Variation. Body size 3.0–4.0 mm. Antenna with 26–31 flagellomeres.
Male. Unknown

p.tp:material-citation:
Holotype .
Female ( IBUNAM ). Brasil , Minas Gerais , Lavras , UFLA 21° 30’ 36” S – 44° 54’ 01” W ;
ex
Anadenanthera colubrina seeds
,
25.IV.2019
; A15, FR1, T.C.T. Oliveira col.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Paratypes .
( IBUNAM ). 2 females , same data as holotype. 25.IV.2019 , 1.V.2019
.

Biology. Four adult specimens of
Allorhogas margitae
were reared from three out of 120 pod seeds approximately two weeks after the pods were collected. We carefully examined each pod and seeds, and there was no evidence that suggested that specimens of
Al. margitae
were parasitoids, since there were no remnants of other insects, such as larvae’s cephalic capsule ( Morales-Silva and Modesto-Zampieron 2017 ). Each specimen of
Al. margitae
completed its biological cycle in a single seed. We reared two specimens in the same pod, but multiple exit holes suggest there were at least three specimens of
Al. margitae
consuming different seeds from the same pod (
).

We found other fruits of
An. columbrina
with similar seed predation patterns and exit holes; however, the insects appeared to have exited the pods before we collected them. We observed 10 unidentified Curculionidae ( Coleoptera ) specimens consuming seeds of this plant species. However, we did not observe whether they were co-existing in the same fruit. The seeds are stenospermic, with their shape ranging from round to reniform; The shell is rough, leathery, glabrous, brown and highly polished, with the presence of stretch marks and ripples ( Barretto & Ferreira 2011 ). Each pod has between 5 to 10 seeds ( Lorenzi & Matos 2002 ). We also observed that the type specimens of
Al. margitae
consumed almost all content of the seed before its emergence, and no galls were observed in the fruit or seeds (
).

Etymology. The specific epithet of this species is given homage to the mother of the senior author, Elsa Margit Talamonte, who has always supported and encouraged her during all her life to do what she loves.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
This study increases the knowledge about the taxonomy, biology, and ecology of the braconid wasp genus
Allorhogas
, describing two new species from Brazil which feed on seeds of two Fabaceae species. In a recent phylogenomic study based on ultraconserved element data, Samacá-Sáenz et al . (2022) confirmed that
Allorhogas
was not monophyletic, though most of their members were nested in a main clade that was further divided into various subclades, each comprising species that shared a same host plant family. One of these subclades was composed of species that are seed predators or make galls on seeds. Our two described species appear to belong to this last subclade based on their biology and on their morphological features.

The external morphology of the
Allorhogas species
that have been reared from leguminous pod seeds is highly conservative, making difficult to morphologically distinguish them. We successfully implemented the DNA barcoding technique to assess the species limits of our two newly described species. Our study increases the number of
Allorhogas species
described from Brazil to 21, and reports for the first time the seed predation of a species of
Allorhogas
in the Fabaceae genus
Anadenanthera
.

The
Allorhogas species
described in this study have a tridentate mandible. This morphological feature has been previously reported in
Allorhogas species
that have been reared from leguminous seed pods (
). This feature is possibly related to the particular phytophagous strategy of these wasp species, and also related to their feeding on lignified plant tissue. Further evidence is needed to link this morphological feature to the natural history of the members of the seed-feeding
Allorhogas
species-group.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We thank Susana Guzmán for her help with the stereomicroscope digital pictures, Cristina Mayorga for her help with the curation of the type material, and Laura Márquez, Andrea Jiménez and Nelly López for their help in the laboratory. TCTO thanks the “Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico” (CNPq-process number 141129/2018-2) for the doctoral scholarship and financial support for this research and the scholarship granted, and to the “Coordenaç„o de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior” (CAPES-process number 88887.572392/2020-00) for her Sandwich scholarship.This study was supported by grants given by the “Coordenaç„o de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior” (CAPES) (CAPES-process number 307889/2021-1), “Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico” (CNPq-process number 306196/2018-2), and “Fundaç„o de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de Minas Gerais ” (FAPEMIG-process number APQ-02700-17) to LDBF, and by grants given by the National Council of Science and Technology (CONACyT, convocatoria de Ciencia de Frontera 2019, project no. 58548) and DGAPA-UNAM (convocatoria 2022, project. no. IN201622 to AZR.
